There is an ongoing debate about the best way to ensure that the Supreme Court of Canada is composed of highly qualified judges who can make just and equitable decisions. Some argue that appointments should be based solely on merit, as this would maximize the likelihood of appointing the best-qualified judges. 

Others, however, argue that diversity is an important consideration in appointments to the Supreme Court of Canada. They believe that appointing judges with a range of backgrounds and experiences can lead to more just and equitable decisions. 

The issue is not whether merit or diversity is more important, but rather how best to balance the two. It is important to recognize that merit and diversity are not mutually exclusive and that a more inclusive judiciary can better understand and address the diverse perspectives of the society.

In Canada, the judicial appointments process seeks to identify highly qualified candidates who exhibit a high degree of professional excellence and integrity, as well as commitment to public service. Simultaneously, the government has led efforts in appointing a more diverse group of judges to the Supreme Court of Canada. 

Ultimately, the balance between merit and diversity in judicial appointments is a subject of ongoing discussion and debate. While both considerations are important, striking the right balance between the two remains a matter of judgment and decision-making.
